Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Scalable Nanomanufacturing of Metasurfaces & Plasmonic Opto-Mechanical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanoarchitectures with subwavelength-sized metallic building blocks arranged on surfaces manipulate light matter interactions. These nanoengineered materials basically lay the foundation for a new, engineered way of controlling light, and pave the way for novel functional devices, unattainable with conventional optics benefitting applications including sensing, energy, imaging, and light guiding. Yet the lack of scalability for large-scale and low-cost production of these nanoarchitectures limits impact. This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) research program will provide disruptive manufacturing solutions to create nanoarchitectures embedded in micron scale surface to foster a breakthrough in scalable fabrication. The investigators will work closely with an industrial advisory board to tailor research that addresses scientific studies to the benefit of a broad range of technology sectors that includes medical and industrial diagnostic systems to optical communications as well as the precision manufacturing equipment needed to achieve the goal of scalable nanomanufacturing. The research program is closely integrated with a diverse educational plan and robust industry outreach that is designed to train students (high school to graduate level, STEM educators/learners and industry practitioners) to be future leaders in science and technology to benefit innovation and strengthen manufacturing in the United States. This plan includes creation of movies and demonstrations in collaboration with the UC Irvine School of Education "From Lab to Lesson Plan" that train high school teachers from the Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA) program serving underrepresented students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). Undergraduate students will be recruited from The Louis Stokes for Minority Participation in STEM, a statewide initiative funded by the National Science Foundation, to train a diverse group of students in advanced research activities. Interdisciplinary training will be provided for graduate students involving fundamental science and engineering as well as technological applications and scientific communication.

Synergistic experimental and theoretical studies involve understanding driving forces that direct assembly of nanoparticles from colloidal solution into predefined surface patterns, physical mechanisms of direct writing of periodic and aperiodic nanowire arrangements using elecromechanical spinning technology, and needed precision in process control. These studies when integrated with existing lithographic techniques will produce multi-length scale complex architectures using high throughput manufacturing methods that afford tunable properties at infrared and optical frequencies while retaining low cost. Test bed applications of these systems include sensors exhibiting low detection limits over large areas, non-linear optical devices, and optical antennas and actuators to demonstrate the benefit to technological applications. Advancements to the research field will be threefold: 1) studies of fundamental mechanisms in nanofabrication will allow researchers to conceive new and robust nanofabrication methods that will benefit research beyond optics, 2) the understanding of defect tolerance in the development of optically responsive surfaces and optomechanical systems will provide guidelines for geometric tolerances in nanomanufacturing, and 3) new insights into the physical mechanism of multi-length scale electromagnetic interactions will improve understanding of novel light-matter interactions and produce improved functionalities for future optical devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed fundamental scientific challenges to enable large area manufacturing of optical devices with nanoscale elements and creating a scientific foundation for combining multiple functionalities in the devices.  While low throughput nanoscale fabrication tools (e.g., electron beam lithography and focus ion beam milling) have produced compact, planar structures able to manipulate electromagnetic waves, scalable nanomanufacturing techniques are less common and often have poor reproducibility. New fabrication methods using self-organization from colloid and electromechanical spinning (EMS) were investigated to form periodic metallic and dielectric nanostructures and multi-length scale architectures as the basis of optical metasurfaces and plasmonic opto-mechanical systems.  In terms of manufacturing, the team designed new architectures in ways that are compatible with large area nanofabrication in order to engineer physical properties.  Integrated platforms for compact optical biosensors and room temperature thermal sensors were designed, fabricated, and characterized.

Intellectual Merit: Studies of: 1) rheology, electrostatic interactions, and molecular precursors during electromechanical spinning (EMS) of nanowires led to understanding how to control spacing of nanowires and produce ?graphene-like? nanowires with high conductivity and integrated electrodes over large area using high throughput methods; 2) driving forces during 2D self-assembly of nanoparticles (NPs) from colloid led to understanding how to produce sensors able to reproducibly detect single-molecule events in complex fluids and obtain control of chemistry in plasmonic architectures.  (This provides a new experimental platform for understanding near field effects in photocatalysis); 3) geometric parameters led to understanding design rules for compact detectors and sensing systems and elucidated manufacturing tolerance. Near-field EMS allows for precise control of nanopatterns on surfaces with feature sizes on the scale of 50 nm with writing speed of 1 m/s.  This allows for versatile patterns of transparent, conductive materials for electrochemical sensors, flexible electronics, and supercapacitors. In terms of optical sensors, investigators demonstrated a manufacturing route for large area assemblies of nanoarchitectures that perform better than commercial surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensors using molecular vibrational spectra to fingerprint molecules.  An important metric for many applications is the ability to distinguish between molecules with similar chemical structure.  Analysis of the vibrational spectra with deep learning algorithms was demonstrated as a method for differentiation and further was able to determine the source direction of molecules in the vapor for monitoring toxins in the environment.  The team has overcome challenges in nanofabrication that enables reproducible single molecule limits of detection across 1 mm2 using low-cost fabrication methods.  This reproducibility allows for quantification as well as detection. In biological applications, the biomarker of interest may be present in the absence of disease and thus quantification is necessary for diagnostic applications.  

   Broader Impacts: An important outcome of this completed program under the Nanotechnology Signature Initiatives was developing large-area manufacturing methods that provide a strong foundation for utilizing nanomaterials in applications including opto-mechanical antennas, sensors, and actuators, and enhancing properties of non-linear devices. The PIs worked closely with an industrial advisory board to address needed scientific studies to benefit technology. Some examples of devices that were enabled by the fundamental studies are optomechanical systems using nanowires coupled to waveguide structures for thermal sensing at room temperature and 2) optical sensors able to quantify down to 10 fM in complex fluids, for diagnostics and water quality assessment, and used to develop new chemometric methods for fundamental research. The proposal has led to training of 7 PhD students, 6 MS students, 6 undergraduates, and 2 high school students. Both high school students are female. One is currently enrolled in an undergraduate program at UC Berkley. She participated in a scientific publication and conference presentations.  The other student participated in outreach events and is currently applying to undergraduate programs in STEM. The other The PIs work with teachers from Central Valley High School (CVHS), a charter school serving underserved (low-income and URM) populations, to increase the pipeline of diverse students entering STEM programs.  Outreach activities included educate high school teachers and students on science and technology of manufacturing nanoscale devices. Hands on use of 3D printers piqued the interest of several students to pursue a major in Materials Science and other STEM disciplines.  Overall the activities led to URM students pursuing undergraduate STEM degrees at UC Irvine and other institutions.  Also, in accordance with the data management plan, this research thus far has produced 2 books, 1 book chapter, three filed record of inventions by the investigators, 25+ peer-reviewed manuscripts, 10+ conference proceedings (the majority are peer-reviewed), and numerous conference presentations.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project addressed fundamental scientific challenges to enable large area manufacturing of optical devices with nanoscale elements and creating a scientific foundation for combining multiple functionalities in the devices. While low throughput nanoscale fabrication tools (e.g., electron beam lithography and focus ion beam milling) have produced compact, planar structures able to manipulate electromagnetic waves, scalable nanomanufacturing techniques are less common and often have poor reproducibility. New fabrication methods using self-organization from colloid and electromechanical spinning (EMS) were investigated to form periodic metallic and dielectric nanostructures and multi-length scale architectures as the basis of optical metasurfaces and plasmonic opto-mechanical systems. In terms of manufacturing, the team designed new architectures in ways that are compatible with large area nanofabrication in order to engineer physical properties. Integrated platforms for compact optical biosensors and room temperature thermal sensors were designed, fabricated, and characterized. Intellectual Merit: Studies of: 1) rheology, electrostatic interactions, and molecular precursors during electromechanical spinning (EMS) of nanowires led to understanding how to control spacing of nanowires and produce ?graphene-like? nanowires with high conductivity and integrated electrodes over large area using high throughput methods; 2) driving forces during 2D self-assembly of nanoparticles (NPs) from colloid led to understanding how to produce sensors able to reproducibly detect single-molecule events in complex fluids and obtain control of chemistry in plasmonic architectures. (This provides a new experimental platform for understanding near field effects in photocatalysis); 3) geometric parameters led to understanding design rules for compact detectors and sensing systems and elucidated manufacturing tolerance. Near-field EMS allows for precise control of nanopatterns on surfaces with feature sizes on the scale of 50 nm with writing speed of 1 m/s. This allows for versatile patterns of transparent, conductive materials for electrochemical sensors, flexible electronics, and supercapacitors. In terms of optical sensors, investigators demonstrated a manufacturing route for large area assemblies of nanoarchitectures that perform better than commercial surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensors using molecular vibrational spectra to fingerprint molecules. An important metric for many applications is the ability to distinguish between molecules with similar chemical structure. Analysis of the vibrational spectra with deep learning algorithms was demonstrated as a method for differentiation and further was able to determine the source direction of molecules in the vapor for monitoring toxins in the environment. The team has overcome challenges in nanofabrication that enables reproducible single molecule limits of detection across 1 mm2 using low-cost fabrication methods. This reproducibility allows for quantification as well as detection. In biological applications, the biomarker of interest may be present in the absence of disease and thus quantification is necessary for diagnostic applications. Broader Impacts: An important outcome of this completed program under the Nanotechnology Signature Initiatives was developing large-area manufacturing methods that provide a strong foundation for utilizing nanomaterials in applications including opto-mechanical antennas, sensors, and actuators, and enhancing properties of non-linear devices. The PIs worked closely with an industrial advisory board to address needed scientific studies to benefit technology. Some examples of devices that were enabled by the fundamental studies are optomechanical systems using nanowires coupled to waveguide structures for thermal sensing at room temperature and 2) optical sensors able to quantify down to 10 fM in complex fluids, for diagnostics and water quality assessment, and used to develop new chemometric methods for fundamental research. The proposal has led to training of 7 PhD students, 6 MS students, 6 undergraduates, and 2 high school students. Both high school students are female. One is currently enrolled in an undergraduate program at UC Berkley. She participated in a scientific publication and conference presentations. The other student participated in outreach events and is currently applying to undergraduate programs in STEM. The other The PIs work with teachers from Central Valley High School (CVHS), a charter school serving underserved (low-income and URM) populations, to increase the pipeline of diverse students entering STEM programs. Outreach activities included educate high school teachers and students on science and technology of manufacturing nanoscale devices. Hands on use of 3D printers piqued the interest of several students to pursue a major in Materials Science and other STEM disciplines. Overall the activities led to URM students pursuing undergraduate STEM degrees at UC Irvine and other institutions. Also, in accordance with the data management plan, this research thus far has produced 2 books, 1 book chapter, three filed record of inventions by the investigators, 25+ peer-reviewed manuscripts, 10+ conference proceedings (the majority are peer-reviewed), and numerous conference presentations.
